page.title: 02CUFFLEY AND NORTHAW-ORIGINS.
page.content: The name Cuffley first appeared as Kuffele in 1228.Through the years it had many different spellings until 1600 when it became Cuffley.It is thought to come from a personal name Cuffa and leah meaning a clearing in a wood.In 948 Northaw was known as North Haga or Northaga meaning North Enclosure.In 1750 it became known under its present name,having been North Haugh and North Hall.Neither village was mentioned in the original Domesday Book. Evidence of a Roman road through the village was found when Cuffley hall was built in 1971. However,there is no evidence of settlement in Cuffley during the Roman period and the road was probably soon engulfed by woodland.In 1842 a cottage was licensed as The Plough beerhouse. The 1851 Census showed eighty people living in Cuffley.
